question:

Question Text: What is the value of \( A \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 3 \)
Answer B Text: \( 4 \)
Answer C Text: \( 6 \)
Answer D Text: \( 9 \)

question:
Question Text: Which digits will change when I subtract \( 20 \) from \( 10,000 \) ?
Answer A Text: All the digits will change
Answer B Text: Only the tens will change
Answer C Text: The tens and the ones will change
Answer D Text: All the digits apart from the ones will change
turns: [{'role': 'student', 'content': 'hello'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Zara, would you like some help with this question?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'how are you'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'm good thanks, how are you?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'im stuck on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's have a look together."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, we're thinking about place value in this question.  10,000 is ten thousand.  And 20 is twenty or two tens."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Let's think about an easier number first...it might help. What is 100-20?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '80'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, so which digits changed when you did that sum?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'the tens and then there were no hundreds left'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, great!  So the hundreds and the tens changed. So, do you think this would be the same for 10,000 or if you're not sure we could look at 1000 first?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So, what is 1000-80?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '200'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'm still just taking tens away...in fact I meant to say 1000-20, so have a go at 1000-20."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '800'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "1000-200=800, but we're doing 1000-20, have another go?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh that would be 980'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great!  Well done! and then getting to the question above, what is 10,000-20?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '9800'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Nearly...you've taken away 200, but you only need to take away 20."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh that is 9980'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great!  You can probably see a pattern emerging.  But now, you know the answer to your question above, which answer is it?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'is the answer d'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes!  Great work, Zara!  I'll leave you to enter your answer now if you're happy with this?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': ':-) Well done!'}]

question:
Question Text: Martha has \( \frac{2}{3} \) of a whole cake in the fridge. Edward eats \( \frac{1}{3} \) of this piece. What fraction of the whole cake has Edward eaten? Choose the number sentence that would solve the word problem.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{1}{3}+\frac{2}{3} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{2}{3} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{2}{3} \div \frac{1}{3} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{3} \)

Answer D Text: \( (16-6+4) \div 2 \)

Answer A Text: \( 7+4 \times 5 \)
Answer B Text: \( 19+16 \div 2 \)
Answer C Text: \( 10+44 \div 2 \)
Answer D Text: \( 60-3 \times 11 \)

question:
Question Text: A greengrocer makes a stack of \( 45 \) melons and \( 60 \) grapefruits. He wants to make a mini version of the stack but only has \( 24 \) grapefruits. How many melons does he need to makes the stacks similar?
Answer A Text: \( 18 \)
Answer B Text: \( 9 \)
Answer C Text: \( 20 \)
Answer D Text: \( 24 \)

question:
Question Text: A greengrocer makes a stack of \( 45 \) melons and \( 60 \) grapefruits. He wants to make a mini version of the stack but only has \( 24 \) grapefruits. How many melons does he need to makes the stacks similar?
Answer A Text: \( 18 \)

Answer A Image: A straight line graph showing Canadian dollars on the y axis up to 10 and Pounds on the x axis up to 20. With a straight line, with a positive gradient, from the origin

Answer C Image: A straight line graph showing Canadian dollars on the y axis up to 20 and Pounds on the x axis up to 10 with a straight horizontal line from 20 on the y axis.
Answer D Image: A straight line graph showing Canadian dollars on the y axis up to 20 and Pounds on the x axis up to 10. Straight line with a positive gradient drawn from approx 5 on the y axis

question:
Question Text: Add brackets to this calculation so that the answer is \( 5 \) \[ 22-10+8 \div 4 \]
Answer A Text: \( 22-(10+8) \div 4 \)
Answer B Text: \( (22-10)+8 \div 4 \)
Answer C Text: \( (22-10+8) \div 4 \)
Answer D Text: \( 22-10+(8 \div 4) \)

question:
Question Text: There are \( 72 \) conkers in a bag. Kai takes \( \frac{1}{3} \) of them. Sophia takes \( \frac{4}{6} \) How many do they have in total?
Answer A Text: \( 72 \)
Answer B Text: \( 0 \)
Answer C Text: \( 24 \)
Answer D Text: \( 48 \)

question:
Question Text: Amira has \( 6 m \) of rope. She cuts it into fifths. How long is each piece?
Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{l}1 \mathrm{~m} \text { and } \\ 200 \mathrm{~cm}\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( \begin{array}{c}1 \mathrm{~m} \text { and } 2 \\ \mathrm{~mm}\end{array} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{c}1 \mathrm{~m} \text { and } 2 \\ \mathrm{~cm}\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( 1 \mathrm{~m} \) and \( 20 \) \( \mathrm{cm} \)

question:
Question Text: \( x y=715000 \) to \( 3 \) significant figures
Question Text: \( x=20 \) to \( 1 \) significant figure
Question Text: Which of these is the minimum value of \( y \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 47700 \)
Answer B Text: \( 35750 \)
Answer C Text: \( 28580 \)
Answer D Text: \( 28620 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello again Leilani!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "hi. I don't understand what to do"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'There are a few steps here. So, to find the minimum value of y, we first need to work out the minimum value of xy.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '35750?#'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "xy = 715000 to 3 sf. So what's the lowest it could have been before it was rounded?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '714500?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, that works for me. So, the smallest we're going to get to is 714500 by doing xy. If we want to find the smallest possible value of y, then we need x to be as BIG as possible. What's the biggest x could be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '19'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's smaller than 20"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '24'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Nearly, but like the last question we worked on together, the upper bound will be the first number that would round up to 30. so that anything even slightly smaller than it would round down.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'to 20. Yes, spot on. So, we have xy = 714500 (its smallest possible) and x = 25 (biggest possible).'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so is it C'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'You beat me to it! Yes, 714500/25 gets you C. Would you like to ask any more questions? Or shall I pass you back to Eedi?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes please'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Will do!'}]

So what's the lowest it could have been before it was rounded?", 'student': '714500?'}, {'turn': 4, 'teacher': "Yes, that works for me. So, the smallest we're going to get to is 714500 by doing xy. If we want to find the smallest possible value of y, then we need x to be as BIG as possible. What's the biggest x could be?", 'student': '19'}, {'turn': 5, 'teacher': "That's smaller than 20", 'student': '24'}, {'turn': 6, 'teacher': 'Nearly, but like the last question we worked on together, the upper bound will be the first number that would round up to 30. so that anything even slightly smaller than it would round down.', 'student': '25'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': 'to 20. Yes, spot on. So, we have xy = 714500 (its smallest possible) and x = 25 (biggest possible).', 'student': 'so is it C'}, {'turn': 8, 'teacher': 'You beat me to it! Yes, 714500/25 gets you C. question:
Question Text: \( Â£ 13000 \) is invested at \( 5 \% \) compound interest per annum. What is the total interest earned after \( 4 \) years?
Answer A Text: \( Â£ 2600 \)
Answer B Text: \( Â£ 2801.58 \)
Answer C Text: \( Â£ 15600 \)
Answer D Text: \( Â£ 15801.58 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hey! How can I help? ğŸ˜ƒ'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hey. i dont know the answer to this please can you help me'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Of course. Let's call the initial investment 100%. if we have 5% interest what % do we have?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '105%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. What is 105% as a decimal?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1.05'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect. Now we want to multiply the 13000 by 1.05 to the power of the number of years. Do you have a calculator?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yeppe'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '13000 x 1.05^4 ='}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '15801.58125'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. So that is the total we now have. The question asks for just the interest'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ok'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How would we work out what the interest is?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'idk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'The interest is the difference between what we invested and what we now have'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'kk'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '15801.58 - 13000'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2801.58'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! question:
Question Text: A house increases in value by \( 12 \% \) each year. After how many full years will the value of the house have at least doubled in price?
Answer A Text: \( 6 \)
Answer B Text: \( 9 \)
Answer C Text: \( 7 \)
Answer D Text: \( 8 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Amelia!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i dont understand the house question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's have a look. So, the percentage we have is 0.12. To calculate an increase by 12%, what will the multiplier be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, 12%, but we would be multiplying by 1.12 to get the new value each year. Does this make sense?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'where did you get 1.12 from'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "It's multiplying by 112%, 100% is the original value. and then we're adding 12% as well"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'ohh okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And we want the house price to at least double. So what percentage are we looking for (double the original value)?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '112?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Not quite....we're multiplying by 112% each year, but. we need to keep doing that until the value doubles...so until we get to 200%"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh right'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, so let's try this... CAn you calculate 1.12 x 1.12?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1.2544. but why do you do 1.12 x 1.12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Because we want to know how many times we need to increase by 12% (multiply by 1.12) until the value has doubled...'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh right okay'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "And we want the price to double... it will have doubled when we reach 200%... which is when we get to 2, because we're working with decimals"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh i get it now'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "So, we need to multiply by 1.12 again... and keep going until you get an answer of 2 or bigger... and remember how many times you've multiplied by 1.12 becuase that will be the answer... So, far you've done 1.12 x 1.12 = 1.2544. so this is for 2 years. Then multiply again by 1.12 to get the percentage increase after 3 years"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so do i keep doing 1.12 x 1.12 till i get to 2 or more'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes ğŸ‘'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'okay i get it now thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Well done! Bye for now ğŸ‘‹'}]

question:
Question Text: A house increases in value by \( 12 \% \) each year. After how many full years will the value of the house have at least doubled in price?
Answer A Text: \( 6 \)
Answer B Text: \( 9 \)
Answer C Text: \( 7 \)
Answer D Text: \( 8 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hey! How can I help? ğŸ˜ƒ'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Hi, I don't know how to work out this question"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "With a question like this we can pick a starting value to work with. Let's say the house was Â£100 (it doesn't matter that it's a really low value). If Â£100 increased by 12% how much would it be worth?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '112 pounds'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. For the house to have at least doubled in price, what do we need the price to get to?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '200 pounds'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great. If 112 increases by 12% what would we get to?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '125.44?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect. No. 6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '6 times gets us to 197.38'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so 7'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, 7 gets us to 221.07. Are you confident using decimal multipliers for compound interest?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'A bit'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'what would be the decimal multiplier for increasung by 12%? *increasing'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.12. 1/12. 1.12'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': '1.12 is correct, well done'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Typos ğŸ˜…'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'another way we could have answered this is to try the years with the decimal multiplier. we could have tried 100 x 1.12^6 for answer A. 100 x 1.12^9 for answer B'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh I get it now! wow, I overthink this question a lot'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'and seen which one gave us the answer over and closest to 200. Are you happy to head back to the lesson? ğŸ™‚'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yeah! ğŸ˜„'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great. Bye!'}]

question:
Question Text: A jacket is reduced in a sale by \( 10 \% \). A customer has a loyalty card for a further \( 5 \% \) off the price.  What is the overall percentage decrease in the price of the jacket?
Answer A Text: \( 15 \% \)
Answer B Text: \( 4.5 \% \)
Answer C Text: \( 0.5 \% \)
Answer D Text: \( 14.5 \% \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'i am not sure how to answer this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Let me take a look. Ok, let's say it started at Â£100 (we could choose any number but 100 is nice when working with percentages). It is first reduced by 10%. What price would it now be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '90'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So the jacket is now Â£90. What happens next?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'the customer has a loyalty card for 5%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'great! So we need to take off 5% of Â£90'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Â£85.5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! Now we need to work out the overall percentage reduction. The jacket started at Â£100 and eded at Â£85.5. So what percentage did it decrease by?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '15%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'not quite. That would take me down from Â£100 to Â£85'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'oh 14.5%'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'That\'s it! It\'s one that tricks everyone. Because the 5% wasn\'t 5% of the original price, it was 5% of the discounted price, so slightly less. Always best with these ones to choose Â£100 as your starting value and do it in stages. I hope that helped"'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'it did thanks'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': ':)'}]

question:
Question Text: Lina turns clockwise from facing \( \mathrm{NW} \) to facing \( \mathrm{S} \)  How many degrees has Lina turned?
Question Image: A image of a compass.
Answer A Text: \( 225^{\degree} \)
Answer B Text: \( 315^{\degree} \)
Answer C Text: \( 135^{\degree} \)
Answer D Text: \( 180^{\degree} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Zuri, would you like help with this question?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "Yes please. I don't really understand how many degrees it takes from NW to N and how much it would take overall"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem. How many degrees in a full turn?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '360'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Yes, well done! And how many degrees between W and N?  Which is also a quarter turn. Hi Zuri! Do you know how many degrees there are between W and N? It's a right angle, so how many degrees is that?  If you're not sure, let me know."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "90 degrees. But it's not an option here"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, great, no that's not the final answer, we're just working it out. We first need to get from NW to N.  NW is half way in between W and N, so how many degrees will that be?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '180 plus 90. 270'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "You're nearly there, you've got the 180 part right - because that's how far it is from N to S. But we need to add on NW to N, which is half of the turn from W to N, so half of 90 degrees.  Let me know if that makes sense?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "So that's 315 degrees"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Can you tell me what numbers you're adding togther?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '45 + 270'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, from NW to N is 45 degrees and then from N to S is 180 degrees.  This is the full journey from facing NW to turning anti-clockwise to S.  SO it would be 180+45.  Is there a part of this that you are unsure of? Sorry!  That should say CLOCKWISE!  I've written it wrong above!  Clockwise from NW to S."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm sure of everything now. Thanks for helping me. Again"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No problem at all! :-)  Keep up the good work, I'll leave you to it."}]

- An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.']}, 'turn 5': {'correct': False, 'kcs': ['Recognize angle measure as additive. dialogue: [{'turn': 1, 'teacher': 'Hi Zuri, would you like help with this question?', 'student': "Yes please. I don't really understand how many degrees it takes from NW to N and how much it would take overall"}, {'turn': 2, 'teacher': 'No problem. How many degrees in a full turn?', 'student': '360'}, {'turn': 3, 'teacher': "Yes, well done! And how many degrees between W and N?  Which is also a quarter turn. Hi Zuri! Do you know how many degrees there are between W and N? It's a right angle, so how many degrees is that?  If you're not sure, let me know.", 'student': "90 degrees. But it's not an option here"}, {'turn': 4, 'teacher': "Ok, great, no that's not the final answer, we're just working it out. We first need to get from NW to N.  NW is half way in between W and N, so how many degrees will that be?", 'student': '180 plus 90. 270'}, {'turn': 5, 'teacher': "You're nearly there, you've got the 180 part right - because that's how far it is from N to S. But we need to add on NW to N, which is half of the turn from W to N, so half of 90 degrees.  Let me know if that makes sense?", 'student': "So that's 315 degrees"}, {'turn': 6, 'teacher': "Can you tell me what numbers you're adding togther?", 'student': '45 + 270'}, {'turn': 7, 'teacher': "Ok, from NW to N is 45 degrees and then from N to S is 180 degrees.  This is the full journey from facing NW to turning anti-clockwise to S.  SO it would be 180+45.  Is there a part of this that you are unsure of? Sorry!  That should say CLOCKWISE!  I've written it wrong above!  Clockwise from NW to S.", 'student': "I'm sure of everything now. Thanks for helping me. Again"}, {'turn': 8, 'teacher': "No problem at all! :-)  Keep up the good work, I'll leave you to it.", 'student': ''}]

question:
Question Text: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline Polygon & \begin{tabular}{c}  Number of \\ sides \end{tabular} & \begin{tabular}{c}  Sum of interior \\ angles \end{tabular} \\ \hline Quadrilateral & \( 4 \) & \( 360^{\circ} \) \\ \hline Pentagon & \( 5 \) & \( 540^{\circ} \) \\ \hline Hexagon & \( 6 \) & \( 720^{\circ} \) \\ \hline Heptagon & \( 7 \) & \( ? \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Question Text: What is the missing angle?
Answer A Text: \( 810^{\circ} \)
Answer B Text: \( 1080^{\circ} \)
Answer C Text: \( 1260^{\circ} \)
Answer D Text: \( 900^{\circ} \)

question:
Question Text: These are both regular polygons. Calculate the unknown angle, \( x \).
Question Image: A hexagon and a square are joined together, sharing one side which is the same length. 'x' is the angle on the outside of where these shapes join.
Answer A Text: \( 210^{\circ} \)
Answer B Text: \( 180^{\circ} \)
Answer C Text: \( 225^{\circ} \)
Answer D Text: \( 150^{\circ} \)

question:
Question Text: \(120 \) blue sheep and \( 90 \) yellow sheep are tested for a disease. The pie charts show the results for each type of sheep.  From the tested sheep, are there more blue or yellow with the disease? By how many?
Question Image: diseased \[ 90^{\circ} \]
Question Image: A pie chart showing a major sector coloured white showing 220 degrees and a minor sector coloured yellow containing the word diseased.
Answer A Text: More blue, by \( 30 \)
Answer B Text: More blue, by \( 55 \)
Answer C Text: More blue, by \( 35 \)
Answer D Text: More yellow, by \( 25 \)

question:

Question Text: Four numbers have a mean of \( 6 \). \( \begin{array}{cccc} 4 &5 & ? & 9 \end{array} \) Find the value of the missing number.
Answer A Text: \( 7 \)
Answer B Text: \( 24 \)
Answer C Text: \( 18 \)
Answer D Text: \( 6 \)

question:
Question Text: This graph shows how many people visited a museum.
Question Image: Chart showing number of viewers against year
Question Text: How many more people visited in \( 2014 \) than in \( 2013 ? \)
Answer A Text: \( 75,000 \)
Answer B Text: \( 350,000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 25,000 \)
Answer D Text: \( 750,000 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Hi Jordan. I'll just take a look at the question for you. The y-axis is titled "Amount in millilitres" and the scale is from 0 to 1500 in steps of 250. The following points are plotted and joined together: (9am, 250), (10am, 375), (11am, 500), (12pm, 750), (1pm, 750), (2pm, 500), (3pm, 625), (4pm, 750), (5pm, 1000), (6pm, 750), (7pm, 500).

Answer A Text: \( 3000 \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer B Text: \( 6750 \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer C Text: \( 4875 \mathrm{ml} \)
Answer D Text: \( 250 \mathrm{ml} \)

question:
Question Text: How far away from home was Natalie at 12:15?
Question Image: A line graph with title "A graph to show the distance Natalie travels from her home on her daily run."  The x-axis is titled "Time" and is labelled with times from 0800 to 1300 in steps of 1 hour, with the axis going half an hour beyond 1300. The y-axis is titled "Distance from home (Km)" and the scale is from 0 to 8 in steps of 1km. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0800, 0), (0830, 2), (0900, 3.5),(1000, 6), (1030, 7), (1100, 7.5),(1230, 7.5),(1300, 4.5), (1330, 0).
Answer A Text: \( 0 \mathrm{~km} \)
Answer B Text: \( 7.5 \mathrm{~m} \)
Answer C Text: \( 750 \mathrm{~m} \)
Answer D Text: \( 7500 \mathrm{~m} \)

question:
Question Text: Expand and simplify: \[ 4(2 x+1)-(5 x-9) \]
Answer A Text: \( 3 x-5 \)
Answer B Text: \( 3 x+13 \)
Answer C Text: \( 13 x-5 \)
Answer D Text: \( 13 x+13 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How can I help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I need help i don't understand"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "No problem, let's look at it together! It looks like you are confident with expanding one bracket, is that true?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great, so in this question we have to expand each bracket on its own, just like you have been doing, then simplify by putting terms together. What did you get when you expanded the first bracket? 4(2x+1) ='}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '8x+4'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect, and then -(5x-9) = ? Remember a - sign on its own is like -1'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '-20x-36'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Just looking at this bracket on its own, multiplying the terms in the bracket by -1'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Huh'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So forget the other bracket with the 4 for now, you have a separate bracket to expand here. You are expanding the bracket -(5x-9)'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '-5x-9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Almost, what happens with -1 x -9? question:
Question Text: Factorise the following expression fully \[ 24 x+72 \]
Answer A Text: \( 2(12 x+36) \)
Answer B Text: \( 24(x+3) \)
Answer C Text: \( 6(4 x+12) \)
Answer D Text: \( 4(6 x+18) \)

question:
Question Text: What is the median number of siblings?
Question Image: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline Siblings(s) & Frequency \( (f) \) \\ \hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\ \hline \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) \\ \hline \( 2 \) & \( 9 \) \\ \hline \( 3 \) & \( 10 \) \\ \hline \( 4 \) & \( 7 \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Answer A Text: \( 4 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2 \)
Answer C Text: \( 3 \)
Answer D Text: \( 10 \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Leila!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi iam dont know hat to do'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Do you know what "median" means?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes. well kind of'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! It's the middle number when all the data is written out in order from smallest to largest. It can seem trickier in a table, but it's the same idea. So, just to show you how it works... The table tells us that 4 people have 0 siblings, do you agree?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'ğŸ‘. So, if this was a list of data it would look like this.... 0,0,0,0,. and then 3 people said they have 1 sibling, so our data list is now... 0,0,0,0,1,1,1..... Do you agree?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great! Now, I don't have to write out all of the data like this...but I'm doing it because when we first learn about medians, we always start by looking at a list of data. If I did keep writing out all the data, how many numbers would I end up writing in total?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '33'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Perfect!  Well done! Ok, so if I wrote out 33 numbers, what is the position of the middle number?   e.g. is it the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th etc?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '16.5. beetween 16 17'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Nearly...well done, you've got the right idea. question:
Question Text: What is the median number of siblings?
Question Image: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline Siblings(s) & Frequency \( (f) \) \\ \hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\ \hline \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) \\ \hline \( 2 \) & \( 9 \) \\ \hline \( 3 \) & \( 10 \) \\ \hline \( 4 \) & \( 7 \) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Answer A Text: \( 4 \)
Answer B Text: \( 2 \)
Answer C Text: \( 3 \)
Answer D Text: \( 10 \)

question:
Question Text: The following table shows the weight of Easter Eggs:
Question Text: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \multicolumn{5}{|c|}{ Weight of Easter Eggs (g) } & Frequency & Mid Point & Mid-Point x Freq & Cumulative Frequency \\ \hline \( 100 \) & \( \leq \) & \( \mathrm{w} \) & \( < \) & \( 200 \) & \( 18 \) & \( 150 \) & \( 2700 \) & \( 18 \) \\ \hline \( 200 \) & \( \leq \) & \( \mathrm{w} \) & \( < \) & \( 300 \) & \( 16 \) & \( 250 \) & \( 4000 \) & \( 34 \) \\ \hline \( 300 \) & \( \leq \) & w & \( < \) & \( 500 \) & \( 10 \) & \( 400 \) & \( 4000 \) & \( 44 \) \\ \hline \( 500 \) & \( \leq \) & \( \mathrm{w} \) & \( < \) & \( 800 \) & \( 12 \) & \( 650 \) & \( 7800 \) & \( 56 \) \\ \hline \( 800 \) & \( \leq \) & \( \mathrm{w} \) & \( < \) & \( 1000 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 900 \) & \( 3600 \) & \( 60 \) \\ \hline \multicolumn{5}{|c|}{ TOTALS } & \( 60 \) & & \( 22100 \) & \\ \hline \end{tabular}
Question Text: What does the circled number represent?
Answer A Text: The total number of eggs that weigh between \( 300 \mathrm{~g} \) and \( 500 \mathrm{~g} \)
Answer B Text: The exact total weight of the \( 10 \) eggs in the \( 300 \) to \( 500 \mathrm{~g} \) category
Answer C Text: The average weight of the Easter Eggs between \( 300 \mathrm{~g} \) and \( 500 \mathrm{~g} \)
Answer D Text: Our best estimate at the total weight of the \( 10 \) eggs in the \( 300 \) to \( 500 \mathrm{~g} \) category

question:
Question Text: You are given data on the lifespan of two different batches of lightbulb, manufactured at the same company. By looking at the data, decide which of the statements below is true. Batch A Mean: \( 1100 \) hours Range: \( 50 \) hours Batch B Mean: \( 800 \) hours Range: \( 400 \) hours
Answer A Text: â€œOn average, batch B's lightbulbs last a shorter length of time and are more consistent"
Answer B Text: â€œOn average, batch A's lightbulbs last a shorter length of time, but are more consistent"
Answer C Text: â€œOn average, batch A's lightbulbs last a longer length of time, and are less consistent"
Answer D Text: "The lifespans for batch A's lightbulbs are more similar to each other than batch B's"

question:
Question Text: A running club has \( 40 \) members.  \( 25 \) of the members take part in road races. \( 12 \) of the members take part in fell races. \( 8 \) of the members do not run in road or fell races.  \( \mathbf{R} \) represents those runners who run in Road races. F represents those runners who run in Fell races.  What is the probability a member takes place in a Road Race but not a Fell Race?
Question Image: Shows an empty venn diagram with each circle labelled R and then F.
Answer A Text: \( \frac{20}{40} \)
Answer B Text: \( \frac{25}{40} \)
Answer C Text: \( \frac{13}{40} \)
Answer D Text: \( \frac{5}{40} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello again!'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "I'm not sure"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok, let's start with putting some numbers on that diagram....so... The running club has 40 members."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'And it gives us facts about how many members in total?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Yes I know that but the wording of the question is weird. It confuses me'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Ok...well I'll try and break it down into stages so we can go through it together. So, how far have you got with the question? I can start at the beginning, or part way through if you've already done some of it?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25 ran road races 12 ran fell races 5 both'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, great...5 both.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "8 just didn't run any"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'perfect. So, we need to know how many do road races only.'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '25'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Nearly...but that 25 will include the ones who did road AND fell'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'Wait I just realised.is it 20,the answer. It changed my words'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great - you ARE a maths genie â­ï¸. Great! Well done! I'll leave you to enter your answer. ğŸ™‚"}]

question:
Question Text: The probability of picking a green ball is \( \frac{1}{5} \) Where is this value on the probability scale?
Question Image: A diagram showing a probability scale with 10 segments. The scale starts at 0.0, has 0.5 marked after 5 segments, and 1.0 marked at the end, after 10 segments. A is marked after 2 segments, B after 4, C after 5 and D after 7.
Answer A Text: A
Answer B Text: B
Answer C Text: C
Answer D Text: D
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi! How are you getting on with this question? ğŸ˜Š'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi i dont understand'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'We can do it together then! So do you know what 1/5 is as a decimal?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.1. ?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "That's 1/10... and 1/5 = 2/10. So 2/10 as a decimal?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0.2'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Great! So 1/5 = 0.2. Now can you see where 0.2 would be located?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'before 0.5'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Great, so that means it's A or B. Is 0.2 closer to 0, or to 0.5?"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '0'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'So which one shall we go for?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'a'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'There we go! Well done! so either try and remember hat 1/5 = 0.2'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'thx'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "Or change 1/5 into 2/10 by doubling both numbers, to jog your memory it's 0.2. You're very welcome, bye Javier!"}]

Answer A Text: A
Answer B Text: B
Answer C Text: C
Answer D Text: D

Answer A Text: \( \begin{array}{c}1 \mathrm{~cm} \text { by } \\ 36 \mathrm{~cm}\end{array} \)
Answer B Text: \( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 9 \mathrm{~cm} \)
Answer C Text: \( \begin{array}{c}6 \mathrm{~cm} \text { by } \\ 6 \mathrm{~cm}\end{array} \)
Answer D Text: \( A, B \) and \( C \)

Answer B Text: \( 750,000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 425,000 \)

Question Text: How many metres did the rocket travel between \( 20 \) and \( 50 \) seconds?

Answer B Text: \( 85 \)
Answer C Text: \( 30 \)
Answer D Text: \( 55 \)

question:
Question Text: How many grams are there in \( 1 \) tonne?

Answer B Text: \( 1000 \)
Answer C Text: \( 2000 \)
Answer D Text: \( 1000000 \)

question:
Question Text: A right-angled tringle has sides a, b, and \( c \) as shown.  Choose the formula for finding side a.
Question Image: Right-angled triangle with height a, base b and hypotenuse c.
Answer A Text: \( a=c-b \)
Answer B Text: \( a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2} \)
Answer C Text: \( a^{2}=b^{2}-c^{2} \)
Answer D Text: \( a^{2}=c^{2}-b^{2} \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Leo how are you?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'hi sylvia, im not sure on his question. this'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "I'm just reading it."}, {'role': 'student', 'content': "wait it's B i think"}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'do you know about Pythagoras Theorem? sorry not B but close'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes, its a squared + b squared = c squared'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'lovely! question:
Question Image: Positive coordinate grid, going up to 8 in both the x and y directions, with the point A labelled at (3,6)
Question Text: Point \( A \) is reflected in the line \( y=3 \). What are the coordinates of the new point?
Answer A Text: \( (2,3) \)
Answer B Text: \( (4,6) \)
Answer C Text: \( (2,0) \)
Answer D Text: \( (0,2) \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi Isabella. What does the line y = 3 look like?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'a line going through the 3 in the y coordinate. going up'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': "It doesn't go up - it's a horizontal line through 3 on the y-axis"}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so across?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'It connects all the points where the y-coordinate is 3. Question Image: A bar diagram showing 45 split into five nines.
Question Text: Which of the following calculations is not represented by the diagram above?
Answer A Text: \( 5=45 \div 9 \)
Answer B Text: \( 5 \times 9=45 \)
Answer C Text: \( 45=9 \times 5 \)
Answer D Text: \( 5 \div 45=9 \)

question:
Question Text: Which statement about the temperatures \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is true?
Answer A Text: \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)  colder than  \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer B Text: \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 12^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)  colder than  \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer C Text: \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) hotter than \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Answer D Text: \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 12^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)  hotter than \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)

question:
Question Image: Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +5 going from -1 up to 4
Question Text: Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
Answer A Text: \( 4+5=-1 \)
Answer B Text: \( -1+5=4 \)
Answer C Text: \( -1+4=5 \)
Answer D Text: \( 1+4=5 \)

Question Text: Which of the following calculations would correctly work out the difference between the temperature at \( 1 \mathrm{pm} \) on Thursday and the temperature at \( 1 \) am on Wednesday?

Answer B Text: \( 7-(-4) \)
Answer C Text: \( 7+(-4) \)
Answer D Text: \( 7-4 \)

question:
Question Text: \( (-5) \div \frac{1}{2}=(-5) \times \square \)
Question Text: What belongs in the box?
Answer A Text: \( 0.5 \)
Answer B Text: \( -2.5 \)
Answer C Text: \( 2 \)
Answer D Text: Not possible

Question Text: Which calculation is equal to \( -20 \) ?
Answer A Text: \( 2 \times(-2)-(-4) \times 4 \)

Answer C Text: \( (-5)^{2}+5 \)
Answer D Text: \( (-42) \div(-2)+1 \)

question:
Question Text: Statement 1: \( \quad p \times(-q)=(-p) \times q \) Statement 2: \( \quad-(q)^{2}=q^{2} \) What can you say about the above statements, where \( p \) and \( q \) represent different numbers?
Answer A Text: Only statement \( 1 \) is true
Answer B Text: Only statement \( 2 \) is true
Answer C Text: Both statements are true
Answer D Text: Both statements are false

question:
Question Text: "Square numbers have an odd number of factors"  Is this statement...
Answer A Text: always true
Answer B Text: sometimes true
Answer C Text: never true
Answer D Text: Impossible to say
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hello Valentina. How can I help you today with factors and multiples. Lets try an example together. Can you think of a square number?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '36'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Brilliant, lets think of the factors of 36. So remember factors are numbers that divide evenly into the number without leaving a remainder. What numbers divide evenly into 36?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '1 36             3 36            4 9        6 6'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Amazing, we have 1 x 36, 4 x 9, 6 x 6, 3 x 12 and there is another factor pair? Think if its even what number definitely goes into 36?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '2 18'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Fantastic Valentina :). So if we were to right the factors for 36 we would say  1,2,3,4,6,9,12,18 and 36. How many factors is this'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '9'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Is this an odd number or even?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'odd'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Excellent, all square numbers have an odd number of factors, can you think why Valentina?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so would it be A always true?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes :). Does this help?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes, thank you very much:)'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'No problem. I will return you to the lesson and just ask if you need any help'}]

question:
Question Text: Which expression should replace the star in the addition pyramid?
Question Image: A diagram showing 3 rows of boxes. the bottom row has 3 boxes, containing 4a, 3b and 3a+b from left to right. The next row up contains two boxes, overlapping the joins of the boxes below. The left one is empty, the right one contains 3a+4b. The top row is one box, centered over the join of the two below, containing a star.
Answer A Text: \( 6 a+5 b \)
Answer B Text: \( 7 a+7 b \)
Answer C Text: \( 14 a b \)
Answer D Text: \( 10 a+8 b \)
turns: [{'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Hi there!  How can I help you? ğŸ˜„'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'can you please help me on this question'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Of course!  Let\'s have a look! Alright, it looks like we are looking for the value of the star here. Let\'s have a look at the block below it, the one that reads "3a +4b". Do you know why they wrote 3a + 4b in that block?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'so you can simplify that'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Yes, they collected like terms to simplify it! Looking at collecting like terms, what would be in the blank block? Above the "4a" and the "3b"?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': '7a+7b? 14ab?'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Close, but not quite...  We can only combine or collect the terms together if they have the same variable.  Do 4a and 3b have the same variable?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'no'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Right, they do not. So we cannot combine or collect them, so we have to leave them separately. So we would write that 4a and 3b combined are 4a + 3b. You can think of it as apples and oranges.  We cannot combine their numbers unless they are the same fruit. How does that sound?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'great'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Awesome!  If it is confusing, please let me know.  The video above is also really helpful in explaining it. So we have 4a + 3b and we need to combine it with 3a + 4b. What would they be if we collected like terms of 4a + 3b and 3a + 4b together?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'how do i click the answer'}, {'role': 'tutor', 'content': 'Would you like me to send you back so you can complete it?'}, {'role': 'student', 'content': 'yes please'}]

Pattern 1 is 6 dots: they are arranged as a rectangle, 4 dots high and 1 dot wide and then 2 more dots in a row to the right of the bottom dot. Pattern 4 is 18 dots arranged as a rectangle, 4 dots high and 4 dots wide and then 2 more dots in a row to the right of the bottom dots.
Answer A Text: Only Jack
Answer B Text: Only Lisa
Answer C Text: Both Jack and Lisa
Answer D Text: Neither is correct

Question Text: \( 3 \) angles meet at a point. Ben and Emma are arguing about them! Ben says the \( 3 \) angles cannot all be acute. Emma says the \( 3 \) angles cannot all be obtuse. Who is correct?
Answer A Text: Only Ben
Answer B Text: Only Emma
Answer C Text: Both Ben and Emma
Answer D Text: Neither is correct
